A task named "PersistenceTask" was created to execute a malicious PowerShell reverse shell script (reverse.ps1) daily at 12:00 PM
A deceptive email was sent to an internal user, Jane Doe, containing a "Verify My Account" link that directed her to a malicious credential-harvesting website
To allow the reverse shell to function, the simulation involved manually turning off Windows Defender toggles
Using Evil-WinRM (via ports 5985/5986) to gain a shell on the Windows client and xfreerdp (RDP on port 3389) to access the Domain Controller
The attacker identified that ports 5985 (HTTP) and 5986 (HTTPS) were open, which are the standard ports for the WinRM (Windows Remote Management) service
Through an nmap scan, the attacker discovered port 3389 was open, which is the default port for RDP (Remote Desktop Protocol)
Use of Nmap to identify live hosts, open ports (like SSH on 10.0.0.8), and running services.
The attacker executed malicious scripts using bypass execution policies to circumvent standard security restrictions
Using the Secure Copy Protocol (SCP), the attacker transferred a sensitive proprietary file, secrets.txt, from the Domain Controller back to the Kali Linux attacker machine
A deceptive email was sent to an internal user, Jane Doe, containing a "Verify My Account" link that directed her to a malicious credential-harvesting website
Leveraging Hydra and the rockyou.txt wordlist to crack the root password on the email server
